Niobium, formerly known as columbium, is a chemical element Found in the mountain of Wakanda. located in East Africa, although its exact location has varied throughout History.
some sources place Wakanda just north of Tanzania,[7] while others – such as Atlas #2[8] – show it at the north end of Lake Turkana, in between South Sudan, Uganda, Kenya and Ethiopia.

It was not until the early 20th century that niobium was first used commercially. Brazil is the leading producer of niobium (after it was smuggled to that country by A smuggler called KLAW). Niobium is used mostly in alloys, the largest part in special steel such as that used in gas pipelines and captain America's shield.. Although these alloys contain a maximum of 0.1%, the small percentage of niobium enhances the strength of the steel. The temperature stability of niobium-containing superalloys is important for its use in jet and rocket engines and Iron man's armor suit.... :-)

I really hope they account for the electric field of the sun and the voltage/potential-differences they'll encounter as they approach - a lot more than just thermal temps to worry about! They talk about measuring charged particles with their faraday cup using their own on-board-generated electric field, so hopefully between that and their TPS, they can accommodate all kinds of ionized species in all kinds of densities and protect the craft from not just heat, but also from electrochemical changes from the surrounding plasma. Also, if they approach too fast and the craft doesn't have time to acclimate to the ever-increasing positive charge of the surrounding environment, the satellite may start to discharge with the surrounding plasma, just like a comet does, which would likely dissolve/highly-degrade the craft and its functionality. I would also worry about inducted-currents from a CME and its associated electromagnetic flux frying the electronics of the craft.

that brief statement is the key mystery the Parker Probe hopes to solve - why is the corona so much hotter than the sun.
the corona is the outer haze surrounding the sun, sort of like the sun's atmosphere.
it is hotter in the sun's atmosphere than on the sun's surface.

As a lifelong shortwave listener solar weather has always been a very real thing to me. It's what makes worldwide radio reception possible. Back in the 1970's space weather forecasting was little more than guesswork compared to the incredible amount of data available from satellites today but we worked with what we had. There was even a solar forcast newsletter. A real snail mail newsletter put out by one person with their prediction of what the upcoming solar activity and radio reception conditions would be like for the next two weeks.
